column4:
…we found that offering a 12-week yoga
program to adults with chronic or recurrent low back pain
led to greater improvements in back function than usual
care for up to 12 months…
column5: …offering a 12-week yoga program to adults with chronic or recurrent low back pain led to greater improvements in back function than did usual care...
column6: …yoga can provide more effective treatment for chronic lower back pain than more conventional methods...
column7: …YOGA 'IS BETTER AT TREATING A BAD BACK THAN GOING TO THE DOCTOR'...
column9: ...YOGA is better for chronic back ache than standard NHS treatments...
column11: …yoga is more effective at alleviating lower back pain...
column12: ...Yoga is more effective in helping people with lower back pain to become more mobile than the conventional treatments GPs offer...
column37: ...a 12-week yoga class led to a small improvement in how well participants could perform daily activities...

column6: Can provide more effective treatment for chronic lower back pain than, experienced greater improvements, can provide both short and long-term benefits, programme may improve back function
column7: Is better at treating, were able to do 30 per cent more daily activities, enabled them to carry out more household chores, helped patients feel more confident
column9: Is better for chronic back ache, 30% more effective, can provide short and long-term benefits
column10: Cure, provides effective pain relief, was far more effective in relieving chronic back pain
column11: Is more effective at alleviating lower back pain, less discomfory, still had less pain
column12: Is more effective, they reported enhanced function, is more beneficial

column4:
...Yoga seems to be a safe and
effective activity that clinicians could consider recommending
for patients with a history of low back pain…
column6: ...The yoga programme offers poses for pain-relief and mental calming; mobilising, stretching, strengthening and relaxation; improving awareness of posture; education about how a healthy back functions; and positive mental focus…
column12:
..."In the past, you were told to lie down until the pain passed," said Prof David Torgerson, of the University of York, who led the study published in the Annals of Internal Medicine.
"Now the advice is to keep your back active.
...
